message: Yeah I'd suggest Facebook and Twitter as well.  I was surprised when I registered and logged in with Facebook that I still had to create a Convore account.  I figured that was the purpose of logging in with FB.

@mridley I could be remembering incorrectly, but I believe the reasoning provided before was that doing it this way allows users to later disconnect their Twitter/Facebook profiles without causing problems with their Convore account.
isn't openID what every site should be using?
@derschnei no. and I second the Google account notion.
@joonas can you summary or link to downside of openid please?
@georgalis This is my favorite argument against OpenID: http://www.quora.com/What-s-wrong-with-OpenID/answer/Yishan-Wong

...the article is a bit shallow; being the perspective of a basic user, not good security. I cannot remember details of OpenID, but what I like is a public system users have to publish their identity, to which they securely associate, to authenticate.

@ericflo thanks for the link.... I don't care about what exactly "openid" is, I just want to use PKI and it seemed closest (just lacks parts). if there is an easy way to get people to adopt managing their own public/private keys, and it comes with identity management (name, standard form data) it would be worlds better than using one or many 3rd party (facebook, twitter, etc) authentications.

It would be so nice if I could just publish/advertise my public keys, and tell websites where to find them when I want an account created for me. Maybe pgp signatures is the fix? (haha)
@ericflo  @georgalis I think that was a good read, thanks for the link. I also enjoy this argument against it from Jeff Atwood: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/04/openid-one-year-later/
"Bah, too much hassle. convore does not support OpenID." http://chat.stackoverflow.com/transcript/message/719063#719063
OpenID support would be a great feature
